definitions.definition: a group of members of the public who listen to the facts of a case in a court and decide whether or not somebody is guilty of a crime, or whether a claim has been proved
definitions.labels: especially in North American English(especially North American English)(especially US English)(especially North American English)(British English)(North American English)

examples.text: The jury has/have returned a verdict of guilty.
the right to trial by jury
A retrial was necessary after the original trial ended with a hung jury.
Her evidence finally swayed the jury.
The jury awarded her damages of £30 000.
The jury convicted Menzies of assaulting Smith.
The jury delivered a unanimous verdict.
The jury were unanimous in their verdict.
The new jury were sworn in.
There were only three women on the jury.

definitions.definition: a group of people who decide who is the winner of a competition

examples.text: He was on the jury for this year's Booker Prize.
He was on a jury judging a songwriting competition.
The jury consisted of an architect, a photographer and an artist.
The jury has awarded the prize for best exhibit in the show to Harry Pearson.
The jury is selected from the winners in previous years.

definitions.definition: used when you are saying that something is still not certain

examples.text: The jury is still out on whether this is a good idea or not.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French juree ‘oath, inquiry’, from Latin jurata, feminine past participle of jurare ‘swear’, from jus, jur- ‘law’.
